The Jin dynasty calls him Dharma Protector.
He was originally from the country of Yuezhi.
His original surname was Zhi.
He lived in the Dunhuang prefecture for generations.
At the age of eight, he left home.

He was then called Zhu by surname. Before the Qin and Jin dynasties, Å›ramaá¹‡as often followed their teachers in calling themselves by surname. Later, due to the influence of Mituo and Dao'an, they generally called themselves ÅšÄkyamuni.
He recited ten thousand words a day and could understand what he saw.
But his nature was pure and his conduct was austere.
He was devoted to learning and sought teachers thousands of miles away.
Therefore, he extensively studied the Six Classics and immersed his mind in the Seven Classics.
Although worldly affairs were criticized, he never harbored them in his heart.
At that time, during the Jin Wudi era,
although temples and images were revered in the capital,
the profound scriptures of the Vaipulya were still in the Western Regions.
Hu therefore sighed and felt indignant, aspiring to spread the great way.
He then followed his teacher to the Western Regions,
traveling through various countries. The foreign languages were of thirty-six types, and the scripts were also like that.
Hu studied them all and mastered them.
He thoroughly understood the pronunciation, meaning, and characters without exception.
He then brought back many Sanskrit scriptures to the Eastern Land.
From Dunhuang to Chang'an,
he later arrived in Luoyang and went to Jiangzuo.
Along the way, he translated and wrote them in Chinese.
Starting in the second year of Emperor Wu's Taishi era (Jingxu),
to the first year of Emperor Min's Jianxing era (Guiyou).
He translated 175 scriptures such as the Prajnaparamita Sutra,ğŸ”½The upasaka Nie Chengyuan,ğŸ”½and his son Daozhen,
Zhu Fachou,
Chen Shilun,
Sun Bohu,
Yu Shiya and others jointly received the instructions of the Dharma Protector and carefully proofread the writings.
But the Dharma Protector was diligent and focused only on promoting and spreading the teachings as his work.
He spent his whole life translating scriptures, never tiring of the effort.
The reason why the scriptures spread widely in the East is due to the Dharma Protector's efforts.
In the end, he secluded himself in a deep mountain.ğŸ”½There was a clear stream in the mountain, which he always used for washing and rinsing.
Later, a woodcutter polluted the water's edge.
In a short while, it dried up.
The Dharma Protector then sighed and said,
Because people lack virtue, it has caused the clear spring to cease flowing.
If the water is forever exhausted, there is truly no way to provide for myself.
I should just move away.
As soon as he finished speaking, the spring flowed and filled the stream.
The moving of his secluded sincerity was all of this kind.
Therefore, Zhi Dun made an image eulogy for him, saying,
The Dharma Protector is clear and tranquil, with profound virtue and elegance.
He faintly chants in the deep valley, and the dried spring gurgles with water. How far away he is!
The Dharma Protector is born with a lofty and noble character.
He wades through the flowing sand and grasps the profound truth.
Later, he established a temple outside the Qingmen of Chang'an. He diligently practiced the Way.
Thus, his virtuous influence spread far and wide, and his reputation covered the four directions.
The number of monks was several thousand, all of whom revered and served him.
When Emperor Hui of the Jin dynasty moved west to Chang'an,
Guanzhong became desolate and the people migrated.
Zhu Shihu fled with his disciples to the east.
He passed away in Weichi due to illness.
He was 78 years old. Zhu Shihu also translated scriptures during the reign of Emperor Min of the Jin dynasty. It is said that when Emperor Hui moved west to Chang'an,
Zhu Shihu fled to the east and passed away in Weichi.
